awd_titl_txt: RR: EAGER: Data Science Literacy for All of Linguistics
awd_abstract_narration:
Like other social and behavioral sciences, linguistic science is inherently data-driven, and the proper care for that data is essential if linguistics is to be a robust, reliable, and reproducible endeavor well into the future. However, many linguists today are still unfamiliar with contemporary practices for handling digital data, and recent work has identified an urgent need for immediate education across most subfields of linguistics about standards and tools for collecting, structuring, archiving, sharing, citing and evaluating linguistic data sets. While some linguistics subfields (language documentation, computational linguistics) have developed strong methods for data handling, outreach to the rest of the discipline has been deficient. This project will radically and rapidly increase the literacy of linguistic scientists at all professional levels in the management of linguistic data, from undergraduate education, to graduate, early- and mid-career training and beyond. This project aims to foster sociological change across the entire discipline of linguistics, and to bring the value of data-handling skills to the forefront of linguistics education, enabling workforce development and potential employment opportunities. Broader impacts include research opportunities in the data sciences for a post-doctoral scholar, downloadable materials with guidelines and metrics for evaluating the scholarship of language data sets for hiring, tenure and promotion, and the development and delivery of formal and informal educational modules on linguistic data management.  


This project is designed to enable linguistics, as a data-driven social science in which inferences about human cognition and social structure are drawn from observations of behavior, is well positioned to benefit from principles of reproducible research.  Currently, there is a disparity between how much digital data is produced by scientists and how much of that data has actually been deposited or made accessible through sustainable repositories or other means.  The team will reduce this disparity by increasing knowledge and resources within the language sciences as part of efforts to change the discipline's culture by reducing structural and knowledge barriers.  These efforts include increasing resources and rewards (such as jobs, tenure, and promotion) for accessible data management practices. Project activities include the rapid development of educational modules at several levels: a massive open online course (MOOC) aimed at undergraduate linguistics majors, and workshops for graduate students and faculty delivered at several widely-attended professional meetings over two years. This will provide a number of offerings and educational modules designed to foster best practices in data handling and data science for reproducible research in linguistics, targeting both junior scholars and mid-career faculty.The project will also disseminate training materials widely throughout the academic linguistic community, through an open-access handbook, online formats, and conference formats. This project takes seriously the contribution of data work as an intellectual achievement in its own right, and will promote methods for increasing the ability and willingness of linguists to effectively create, manage, preserve, curate, and share linguistic data.

por.por_cntn:
Data, in its many forms, underlie the discipline of linguistics in theory, practice and application, and proper management of data collections is essential to the future of our field. Linguistic data has the power to inspire future scientific inquiry into the nature of human language and cognition. During the course of this award we have aimed to increase broad understanding about the current state of the art of linguistic data management and instruct practitioners in best practices in the field.

We have achieved these aims through a multi-pronged educational approach including workshops, an open-access handbook, and an online companion course to the handbook.

We held a sattelite workshop at 2019 Linguistics Society of America Annual Meeting (https://www.linguisticsociety.org/event/lsa-2019-annual-meeting) entitled, "Tools for Reproducible Research in Linguistics." It was run by co-PI Brad McDonnell, post-doc Eve Koller, and Dr. Na-Rae Han, a computational linguist from U Pittsurgh. We had 21 participants attend the workshop, ranging from graduate students to senior scholars. The workshop featured hands-on tutorials in the most important tools for reproducible research, including git, GitHub, Jupyter Notebooks, and Rstudio. All materials for the course available on github.

We held a series of workshops collectively titled "Data Summer Camp: A Wednesday Minicourse on Reproducible Linguistics Research". The series was held as part of the 2019 biannual Linguistics Summer Institute at UC Davis, a 4-week intensive institute for linguists at all levels, from undergraduate through professors. Hundreds of linguists usually attend the institute, and Wednesdays are dedicated to special workshops and conferences. We held thee workshops: A workshop on Knitr and Latex by co-PI Brad McDonnell and Dr. Bradley Rentz; a workshop on how reproducible research can benefit the linguists carreer by Dr. Lauren Collister; and a workshop on git and GitHub by Dr. Na-Rae Han. Approximately 65 people attended the 3 workshops.

Our open access edited volume, The Open Handbook of Linguistic Data Management, was published both online and in hardback by MIT Press Open in 2022. This volume contains 56 chapters written by leading experts in data collection and management from across many subfields of linguistics, including  sociolinguistics, phonetics, phonology, discourse and conversation analysis, language documentation and revitalization, language description, historical linguistics, computational linguistics, syntax, semantics, language acquisition, sign linguistics, typology and corpus linguistics. The first 13 chapters present broad conceptual foundations, principles and implementation of data management, and the remaining chapters are data managemet use cases describing actual data management methods from real studies in the field.

We have also developed a free online companion course to the handbook, found at http://linguisticdatamanagement.org. This self-paced course is designed provide readers an opportunity to delve more deeply into the concepts presented in the first 13 chapters in the Handbook. Each course lesson provides: a link to the relevant chapter; a brief synopsis of the chapter; highlighted core keywords and concepts, so readers can ensure you understand the important points; activities and opportunities to practice what has been learned; suggestions for how implement the concepts in your own career, research and study; quizzes to test your understanding of the concepts; links to the Data Management Use Case chapters that are especially relevant; related readings; and information about the chapter author(s).
